qas.question: Which three statistics does the HDI compile?

answers.text: life expectancy, education, and income per capita

qas.question: Does a high ranking on the HDI indicate shorter or longer life expectancy?
Does a high ranking on the HDI indicate shorter or longer life expectancy at birth?

plausible_answers.text: life expectancy, education, and income per capita indicators

qas.question: Which three statistics does the HDI ignore?
Does a low ranking on the HDI indicate shorter or longer life expectancy?
Does a low ranking on the HDI indicate shorter or longer life expectancy at birth?

context: The Human Development Index (HDI) is a composite statistic of <a0_0><b5_0>life expectancy, education, and income per capita<a0_0/> indicators<b5_0/>, which are used to rank countries into four tiers of human development. A country scores higher HDI when the life expectancy at birth is <a1_0><a4_0><b9_0>longer<b9_0/><a4_0/><a1_0/>, the education period is <b6_0>longer<b6_0/>, and the income per capita is higher. The HDI was developed by the Pakistani economist <a2_0><b7_0>Mahbub ul Haq<b7_0/><a2_0/>, often framed in terms of whether people are able to "be" and "do" desirable things in their life, and was published by the <a3_0><b8_0>United Nations Development Programme<b8_0/><a3_0/>.
